Authors:
Richard J. Butler, Stephen L. Brusatte, Mike Reich,
Sterling J. Nesbitt, Rainer R. Schoch, Jahn J. Hornung
Title:
The sail-backed reptile Ctenosauriscus from the latest Early
Triassic of Germany and the timing and biogeography of the early
archosaur radiation.
Abstract:
Archosaurs (birds, crocodilians and their extinct
relatives including dinosaurs) dominated Mesozoic continental ecosystems
from the Late Triassic onwards, and still form a major component of
modern ecosystems (>10,000 species). The earliest diverse archosaur
faunal assemblages are known from the Middle Triassic (c.Â 244 Ma),
implying that the archosaur radiation began in the Early Triassic
(252.3-247.2 Ma). Understanding of this radiation is currently limited
by the poor early fossil record of the group in terms of skeletal
remains.
